Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Understanding Biomolecular Manufacturing and Assembly of Nanocrystals - Fundamentals and Novel Properties for Solar Energy Harvesting

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) project is to create new DNA-based manufacturing technologies that produce nanostructures capable of efficiently harvesting solar energy. This research will elucidate the underlying physics and chemistry that are pertinent to the oligonucleotide-based nanocrystal synthesis and molecular recognition processes. Theoretical modeling will be developed to guide experimental realization, generating optimal conditions for large-scale nanocrystal production. The fundamental understanding of DNA-programmed manufacturing and assembly will enable the formation of dynamic nanostructures that can convert solar energy through successive system regenerations, similar to what is seen in natural photosystems. The manufactured nanostructures will also serve as a novel platform to study electron and energy transfer mechanisms at the nanoscale.

If successful, the outcome of this research will lead to new manufacturing technologies that transform solar energy utilization. The nucleic acid-based manufacturing and bio-inspirational concept of system regeneration will develop a new paradigm for harvesting solar energy with impacts on the photovoltaic industry. The overall goal of this project is to integrate cutting-edge research and education for sustained impacts on the nanomanufacturing field for alternative energy, while training the next generation of engineers. The project activities will (1) provide opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students to learn and conduct pioneering science and engineering in a multidisciplinary environment, (2) increase participation of women and underrepresented minority students, and (3) make strong impacts on K-12 students through active outreach programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research aimed at discovering fundamental scientific knowledge and engineering principles of DNA-based nanomanufacturing. Synthetic DNA oligonucleotides were used to mediate the nucleation and growth of nanocrystals and to organize the functionalized nanoparticles in a programmable fashion. The nanomaterials were explored for demonstrating bioinspired light harvesting and probed optically for studying the assembly processes at the nanoscale. The outcome of this research includes (1) a detailed understanding of DNA-mediated nanocrystal synthesis, (2) elucidation of DNA-guided assembly of nanoparticles, and (3) demonstration of regenerative light harvesting via reversible self-assembly. In addition, DNA self-assembly was exploited to design and construct biomacromolecules capable of programmable reconfiguration and synthetic molecular motors. The DNA-functionalized nanomaterials were also developed as bioanalytical tools for single-molecule reaction studies. The DNA-manufacturing technologies from this research formed the basis of emerging biomolecular nanotechnology, enabling novel devices with new levels of system control at the nanoscale and providing scientific insights on nanomanufacturing and assembly processes.

 

The project activities included strong efforts integrating cutting-edge research with education and outreach. The research efforts helped create new graduate-level course materials on biomolecular nanomanufacturing. The topics of DNA-based synthesis, nanoparticle assemblies, optical nanoscopy, and related engineering applications were partly incorporated into an existing course and will be fully instituted in a new course. The project team developed a hands-on experimental outreach module titled ‘Glowing Grass: Observation of Photosynthetic Units and Processes’ for K-12 students, parents, and teachers. In this module, green leaves and grass are collected, grinded, and dissolved in ethanol by the participants who can then observe chlorophylls (pigments in plants) through optical visualization. This module helps K-12 students and teachers understand natural photosynthesis through simple hands-on experiments. The project team constructed portable units such that this module can be performed outside lab.

 

This research engaged 8 graduate students and postdoctoral researchers along with the faculty investigator who together published 1 book, 5 book chapters, and 20 journal papers. This project also provided research opportunities for 12 undergraduate students including 7 female and 3 minority students. This program provided a unique multidisciplinary research environment where students of diverse backgrounds learn from each other, becoming engineers and scientists of next generation to solve the challenges of our society.
